Description: This study guide reviews the nature of science and the basics of scientific investigation and experiments. It also compares hypotheses versus theories.
This study guide looks at the characteristics of life, the four unifying principles of biology, and the interdependence of living things.

Authors: Steven Lai; Rory Runser; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide reviews the four basic classes of organic compounds: carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids.

Resource Name: Cells and Cell Structure Study Guide
Authors: Danielle Phan; Rohit Ramkumar; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide provides an overview of cell theory, cell properties, and cell structures. It also compares eukaryotic cells and prokaryotic cells.

Concept EIDs: SCI.BIO.228.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.228.2.L.1, SCI.BIO.228.3.L.1, SCI.BIO.229.L.1, SCI.BIO.229.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.229.2.L.1
Resource Name: Cell Transport and Homeostasis Study Guide
Authors: Rohit Ramkumar; Amy Shen; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide takes a look at homeostasis and transport across membrane by passive transport and active transport.

Concept EIDs: SCI.BIO.216.L.1, SCI.BIO.216.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.217.L.1, SCI.BIO.217.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.231.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.231.2.L.1
Authors: Cindy Lam; Danielle Phan; Jin Yu
Description: How do organisms get energy? This study guide provides an overview of energy-carrying molecules, autotrophs versus heterotrophs, the basics of chemical reactions and activation energy, and enzymes.
This study guide reviews photosynthesis and the two stages of photosynthesis: light reactions and the Calvin cycle.

Authors: Cindy Lam; Rohit Ramkumar; Amy Shen; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide reviews cellular respiration, including the roles of glycolysis, Krebs cycle, electron transport chain and ATP synthase. It also compares aerobic and anaerobic respiration (fermentation).

Concept EIDs: SCI.BIO.236.L.1, SCI.BIO.236.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.237.L.1,  SCI.BIO.238.L.1, SCI.BIO.239.L.1, SCI.BIO.239.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.239.2.L.1
Resource Name: Cell Division and Cell Cycle Study Guide
Description: This study guide gives an overview of the cell cycles for prokaryotes and eukaryotes, names for genetic material, binary fission, mitosis, and cytokinesis.
This study guide compares asexual and sexual reproduction and also looks at meiosis, genetic variation, and life cycles.
This study guide gives an overview of Mendel's pea plant experiments, including experimental steps, results, and conclusions.
This study guide looks at Mendelian inheritance and using Punnett squares to predict genotype and phenotype. It also gives a brief overview of non-Mendelian inheritance.

Resource Name: Human Chromosomes and Genes Study Guide
Description: This study guide reviews the human genome, chromosome type and structure, and genes.
This study guide looks at inheritance that exhibit Mendelian pattern, pedigrees, non-Mendelian inheritance, and genetic disorders.
The science and applications of genetic engineering is the focus of this study guide.
This study guide gives a brief overview of DNA replication.
This study guide takes a look at protein synthesis: the central dogma of molecular biology, genetic code (codons), types of RNA, transcription, and translation.
This is a study guide about mutations: causes, types, and effects.

Resource Name: Regulation of Gene Expression Study Guide
Description: This study guide looks at how genes are regulated in prokaryotes and eukaryotes.

Resource Name: Earth Forms and Life Begins Study Guide
Description: This study guide provides a brief timeline of Earth's history and the origin of life, including RNA world hypothesis and endosymbiosis. It also looks at carbon dating.

Resource Name: Evolution of Multicellular Life Study Guide
Description: This study guide gives a brief overview of important eras in Earth's history: the Late Precambrian Era, Cambrian explosion, Paleozoic Era, Permian extinction, Mesozoic Era, and Cenozoic Era.
The Linnean classification and phylogenetic classification systems are compared in this study guide.

This study guide looks at Darwin's theory of evolution and natural selection. It also looks at some of the evidences supporting the theory of evolution (comparative anatomy, comparative embryology, biogeography).

This study guide takes a look at population genetics, the Hardy-Weinberg theorem, and the forces of evolution, such as genetic drift and natural selection. It also examines how natural selection affects phenotypes.
This study guide examines the meaning of "species" and reviews causes of speciation. It also looks at the timing of macroevolution.
This study guide introduces ecology and looks at how organisms interact with the environment. It also reviews ecosystems, food chains, food webs, and trophic levels.
This study guide looks at three important biogeochemical cycles: water cycle, carbon cycle, and nitrogen cycle.
This study guide reviews terrestrial and aquatic biomes.
This study guide reviews three major types of community interactions: predation, competition, and symbiosis. It also looks at ecological succession.
This study guide looks at ways to describe population and population growth rate.
This study guide reviews human population growth (past, present, and predicted future growth) and demographic transition.
This study guide looks at the importance of biodiversity, the biodiversity crisis, and sixth mass extinction.
This study guide compares renewable and nonrenewable resources. It also provides an overview of several valuable natural resources and global climate change.
This study guide looks at prokaryotes and their classification, structure, reproduction, and role in the world. It also looks at Gram staining.
This study guide looks at some of the characteristics of viruses and the role of viruses in the world.

Concept EIDs: SCI.BIO.621.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.622.L.1, SCI.BIO.623.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.623.2.L.1, SCI.BIO.623.3.L.1, SCI.BIO.628.L.1
Description: This study guide takes a brief look at the general characteristics of protists and three types of protists: protozoa, algae, and mold.
This study guide provides an overview of fungi and their general characteristics, reproduction, and role in the world. It also looks at the types of symbiotic relationships fungi can form.

Concept EIDs: SCI.BIO.711.L.1, SCI.BIO.712.L.1, SCI.BIO.726.L.1, SCI.BIO.713.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.713.2.L.1, SCI.BIO.710.L.1
Description: An introduction to plants and their life cycle, evolution, classification, and importance are covered in this study guide.
This study guide looks at the characteristics, classification, and evolution of nonvascular plants, vascular plants, seed plants, and flowering plants.

Concept EIDs: SCI.BIO.721.L.1, SCI.BIO.722.L.1, SCI.BIO.722.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.723.L.1, SCI.BIO.724.L.1, SCI.BIO.725.L.1, SCI.BIO.726.1.L.1
Resource Name: Plant Tissues and Organs Study Guide
Description: This study guide gives an overview of the characteristics of plant cells, plant tissues, and plant organs (roots, stems, leaves).
An overview of life cycles for nonvascular plants, seedless vascular plants, gymnosperms, and angiosperms is presented in this study guide.

Resource Name: Plant Adaptations and Responses Study Guide
Description: This study guide gives a brief look at plant adaptations to water, dryness, and air, as well as plant responses (tropisms) to external factors and diseases.
This study guides look at animals and their characteristics, animal cells, nine major phyla of animals, invertebrates versus vertebrates, and major points of animal evolution.

Concept EIDs: SCI.BIO.847.L.1, SCI.BIO.848.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.848.2.L.1, SCI.BIO.849.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.849.2.L.1, SCI.BIO.849.3.L.1
Description: An overview of animal behavior, such as innate, learned, social, cyclic, and reproductive behaviors is given in this study guide. It also gives a brief review of the nature-nurture debate.
This study guide covers characteristics of invertebrates (digestive system, movement, reproduction), invertebrate evolution, protostomes vs deuterostomes, and the major invertebrate phyla.

Concept EIDs: SCI.BIO.821.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.821.2.L.1, SCI.BIO.822.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.822.2.L.1, SCI.BIO.823.L.1, SCI.BIO.824.L.1, SCI.BIO.825.L.1, SCI.BIO.826.L.1, SCI.BIO.827.L.1
Description: This study guide summarizes the ecology, body structure, and reproduction of sponges, cnidarians, flatworms, roundworms, mollusks, annelids, arthropods, insects, and echinoderms. It also includes further classification of arthropods and echinoderms.
The structure, reproduction, classification, evolution, and ecology of fish are covered in this study guide.
The structure, reproduction and development, classification, evolution, and diet of amphibians are covered in this study guide.
The structure, reproduction, classification, evolution, and ecology of reptiles are covered in this study guide.
The structure, reproduction, reproductive behavior, development, classification, evolution, and diet of birds are covered in this study guide.
The characteristics, structure, brain size/intelligence, social living, and locomotion of mammals are covered in this study guide.
This study guide looks at mammalian reproduction in placental mammals, marsupials, and monotremes.

Resource Name: Mammals: Evolution and Classification Study Guide
Description: This study guide reviews mammalian ancestors and evolution, as well as the classical and phylogenetic classifications of mammals.
This study guide gives a brief review of the organization of the human body and the importance of maintaining homeostasis.
This study guide looks at the skeletal system and the structure, growth, and development of bones. It also reviews skeletal injury and disease.

Authors: Rohit Ramkumar; Amy Shen; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide reviews the three types of muscles (skeletal, cardiac, smooth) and muscle contraction (sliding filament theory).

Concept EIDs: SCI.BIO.921.1.L.1, SCI.BIO.921.2.L.1, SCI.BIO.922.L.1, SCI.BIO.923.L.1, SCI.BIO.924.L.1, SCI.BIO.925.L.1
Authors: Rohit Ramkumar; Amy Shen; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide reviews the parts of nervous system (central and peripheral), parts of the brain, parts and types of nerve cells, nerve impulses, synapses and communication between neurons, and sense organs.

Authors: Rohit Ramkumar; Amy Shen; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide looks at the endocrine system and the role of hormones, how hormones work, and how hormones are regulated. It also briefly reviews endocrine system disorders.

This study guide provides an overview of the circulatory system: the heart (chambers, valves), blood vessels (arteries, veins, capillaries), blood (components, blood type), pulmonary circuit, systemic circuit, and cardiovascular diseases.

Authors: Courtney Chuang; Rohit Ramkumar; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide reviews the organs of respiratory system, the steps in respiration, the role of the diaphragm in controlling breathing, and respiratory diseases.

Authors: Cindy Lam; Rohit Ramkumar; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide reviews the functions of the digestive system and the path food takes through the digestive system (mouth, esophagus, stomach, small intestines, large intestines).

Authors: Courtney Chuang; Rohit Ramkumar; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide looks at the organs of the excretory system, the urinary system (kidneys, nephron), the role of the kidney in maintaining homeostasis, and kidney diseases.

Concept EIDs: SCI.BIO.941.L.1, SCI.BIO.942.L.1, SCI.BIO.943.L.1, SCI.BIO.944.L.1, SCI.BIO.945.L.1,  SCI.BIO.946.L.1
Resource Name: Immune System Part I Study Guide
Description: This study guide looks at the immune system. It reviews the three lines of defense, lymphatic system, humoral immune response, cell-mediated response, and immunity.

Resource Name: Immune System Part II Study Guide
Description: This study guide reviews allergies, autoimmune disease, and immunodeficiency (HIV and AIDS).
This study guide covers the effects of environmental problems on health. It looks at pollution, carcinogen, and bioterrorism.
This study guide looks at the male reproductive system (penis, testes, ducts, glands), spermatogenesis, and sexual development (puberty, adolescent growth).

This study guide looks at the female reproductive system (vagina, uterus, fallopian tubes), egg production (oogenesis, maturation, ovulation, fertilization), sexual development (puberty, adolescent growth), menstruation, and menopause.

Resource Name: Fertilization to Old Age Study Guide
Description: This study guide outlines the events that occur between fertilization and old age: implantation, embryo and fetus growth and development, pregnancy and childbirth, infancy, adolescence, and adulthood.
This study guide provides an overview of sexually transmitted infections (STIs) and a comparison of bacterial STIs and viral STIs.

Concept EIDs: SCI.PHY.121.L.1, SCI.PHY.123.L.1, SCI.PHY.124.L.1, SCI.PHY.130.L.1, SCI.PHY.120.L.1, SCI.PHY.162.L.1, SCI.PHY.162.1.L.1
Description: A review of the terms distance, displacement, velocity, speed, and acceleration. Also looks at graphs of motion, using the kinematic equations, projectile motion, and free fall.

Concept EIDs: SCI.PHY.142.L.1, SCI.PHY.143.L.1, SCI.PHY.149.L.1, SCI.PHY.147.L.1, SCI.PHY.146.L.1, SCI.PHY.141.L.1
Description: This study guide looks at Newton's three laws, free body diagrams, and types of forces, including the force of gravity, normal force, and friction force.
This study guide provides an overview of potential energy, kinetic energy, and energy conservation, as well as energy diagrams, work, conservative force, and non-conservative force.
This study guide reviews momentum, law of conservation of momentum, impulse, and collisions (perfectly elastic and perfectly inelastic).

Concept EIDs: SCI.PHY.163.L.1, SCI.PHY.163.1.L.1, SCI.PHY.163.2.L.1, SCI.PHY.163.3.L.1, SCI.PHY.260.1.L.1, SCI.PHY.264.L.1, SCI.PHY.267.L.1
Description: This study guide provides an overview of circular and rotational motion: centripetal force, discussion of fictitious force, calculating period and frequency, determining the rotational axis, calculating angular quantities, and precession.
This study guide looks at gravitation, Kepler's laws of planetary motion, and satellite motion.
This study guide reviews simple harmonic motion: restoring force, period, frequency, and damped/driven harmonic motion. It also looks at spring system and pendulum system.
This study guide gives an overview of special relativity and general relativity: a look at time dilation, length contraction, relativistic mass and kinetic energy, twins paradox, and spacetime.

Concept EIDs: SCI.PHY.310.L.1, SCI.PHY.311.L.1, SCI.PHY.317.L.1, SCI.PHY.325.L.1, SCI.PHY.320.L.1, SCI.PHY.318.L.1
Description: This study guide gives an overview of mechanical waves and the characteristics of transverse waves and longitudinal waves. It also looks at wave interaction: interference (constructive and destructive), beat frequency, standing wave, resonance, and the Doppler effect.
This study guide gives an overview of the laws of thermodynamics and heat engines. It looks at the ways heat transfers, specific heat, and thermal conductivity.

This study guide gives a brief overview of the properties of fluids: pressure, Pascal's law, Archimedes' principle, the continuity of fluid flow, Bernoulli's equation and conservation of energy, surface tension, viscosity, and turbulence.
This study guide gives a brief overview of radiation.

This study guide reviews electrostatics: Coulomb's law, properties of charges, electric field, conductive materials (conductors, insulators, semiconductors, superconductors), and charging by conduction or induction.

Concept EIDs: SCI.PHY.430.L.1, SCI.PHY.434.L.1, SCI.PHY.442.L.1, SCI.PHY.444.L.1, SCI.PHY.445.L.1, SCI.PHY.446.L.1, SCI.PHY.448.L.1, SCI.PHY.437.L.1
Description: This study guide is an overview of circuits and circuit diagrams. It discusses voltage, current, Ohm's law, loop rule, and junction rule and reviews how to solve resistors in series, resistors in parallel, capacitors in series, and capacitors in parallel.

This study guide reviews electromagnetism concepts: magnetic field and field lines, first right hand rule, magnetic flux, solenoid, electromagnetic induction, force on charged particle, second right hand rule, and inductance.
This guide looks at geometric optics: reflection, refraction, Snell's law, total internal reflection, ray diagram, real and virtual images, mirrors, and lenses.
This study guide provides a brief review of light's behavior as a wave (interference, diffraction, and Doppler effect).

Resource Name: Basics of Real Numbers Study Guide
Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide reviews the different types of rational numbers and some of their properties: rational number, integer, natural number, whole number, non-integer, fraction, and irrational number. It also looks at symbols used in algebra and sets.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide is an overview of graphing opposite numbers, absolute values, addition/subtraction, and inequalities on number lines.

Resource Name: Working with Real Numbers Study Guide
Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide defines variable, variable expression, and variable equation. It also reviews properties of real numbers (commutative, associative, additive identity, multiplicative identity, distributive) and the order of operations.

Description: This study guide looks at the properties of inequality and solving linear inequalities in one variable, the number of solutions to linear inequalities in one variable, and ways to write the solutions.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide gives an overview of compound inequalities: how to solve them and how to plot the solutions on a number line.

Resource Name: Absolute Value Equations and Inequalities Study Guide
Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide reviews how to solve absolute value equations and inequalities.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide reviews coordinates on the coordinate plane and looks at basic concepts of functions (independent and dependent variables, domain and range).  It also provides an overview of graphing functions and the vertical line test.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide goes over the basics of graphing linear equations: slope, intercept, slope-intercept form, standard form, point-slope form, and converting between different forms of writing linear equations.

Resource Name: Determining the Equation of a Line Study Guide
Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide looks at finding equations for lines (in slope-intercept form, point-slope form, and standard form). It also looks at equations for parallel and perpendicular lines.

Resource Name: Linear Systems: Solve by Graphing and Substitution Study Guide
Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide looks at systems of linear equations and how to solve them by graphing and by substitution. It also looks at the types/number of solutions to systems of linear equations.

Resource Name: Linear Systems: Solve by Elimination Study Guide
Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide looks at solving systems of linear equations by adding/subtracting and by multiplying. It also provides guidelines for solving systems with 3 variables.

Resource Name: Systems of Linear Inequalities Study Guide
Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide gives an overview of graphing linear inequalities in one and two dimensions and graphing systems of inequalities.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide reviews properties of exponents and the exponential form: product rule, quotient rule, power rule for exponents, power rule for quotients. It also looks at how to evaluate zero, negative, and fractional exponents.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide looks at terminology for monomials and polynomials, operations with polynomials, FOIL, and special products (square of a binomial, sum and difference patterns).

Concept EIDs: MAT.ALG.622.L.1, MAT.ALG.632.L.1, MAT.ALG.626.L.1, MAT.ALG.624.1.L.1, MAT.ALG.628.L.1, MAT.ALG.620.L.1
Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide reviews methods to factor polynomials, including identifying special products, factoring monomials, and tips for factoring polynomials completely. It also looks at how factoring can be used to solve polynomial equations.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide takes a look at graphing quadratic functions and identifying features of the parabola. It also reviews how to solve quadratic functions by graphing.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide gives an overview of methods to solve quadratic functions: solving by square roots (special case), completing the square, using the quadratic formula. It also looks at using the discriminant to determine the number of solutions.

Concept EIDs: MAT.ALG.800.L.1, MAT.ALG.840.L.1, MAT.ALG.831.L.1, MAT.ALG.834.1.L.1, MAT.ALG.832.L.1, MAT.ALG.838.L.1
Resource Name: Irrational Numbers and Radicals Study Guide
Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide looks at square and cube roots, radical expressions, rationalization, solving radical equations, and graphing radical functions and equations.

Resource Name: Geometric Sequences and Exponential Functions Study Guide
Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide compares linear, quadratic, and exponential models. It also looks at geometric sequences.

Resource Name: Graphs of Rational Functions Study Guide
Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide looks at variations (direct, inverse, joint), graphing rational functions and how to find asymptotes.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Jin Yu
Description: This study guide gives an overview on simplifying rational expressions, solving rational equations, and removable zeros.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide reviews how to measure the distance between two points and the Ruler Postulate. It also introduces congruency/congruent segments and midpoint.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide reviews angle nomenclature, how to measure angles, different types of angles, congruent angles, and angle pairs.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: Symbolic notation used in logic, inductive reasoning (patterns), and deductive reasoning are the focus of this study guide.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide reviews conditional statements and related conditionals (converse, negation, inverse, contrapositive), biconditional statements, compound statements, and truth tables.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide reviews proofs: algebraic proof, properties of congruence, and geometric proofs (two-column).

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide is an overview of notation and basic postulates/theorems for parallel and perpendicular lines.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide reviews angles formed by transversals and postulates and theorems of parallel and perpendicular lines.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide looks at the slopes of parallel/perpendicular lines and how to graph and derive equations for parallel/perpendicular lines.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide reviews terminology for triangles, different types of triangles, and interior and exterior angles theorems.

Description: This study guide is an overview of triangle congruence: defining corresponding parts of congruent triangles, postulates and theorems for congruences (SSS, SAS, AAS, ASA), and postulates and theorems for congruences for special triangles.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide looks at definitions and theorems for midsegments, bisectors, medians, and altitudes.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide is an overview of the triangle inequality theorem and hinge theorem.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide focuses on polygons: convex vs concave, interior and exterior angles, and basic terminology for common polygons.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide looks at properties of parallelograms and special parallelograms (rectangle, rhombus, square), theorems about parallelograms and special parallelograms, and how to identify special parallelograms.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide looks at properties and theorems about trapezoids and kites.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide reviews ratios, proportions, and cross-multiplication.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide looks at similar polygons, scale factor (ratio), and triangle similarity.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide looks at proportionality theorems for triangles and parallel lines intersected by transversals.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide looks at several examples of self-similarity.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide is an overview of the Pythagorean theorem and its converse, Pythagorean triples, and proving the distance formula.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: An overview of altitudes and geometric mean is provided in this study guide.

Description: This study guide looks at the trigonometric ratios sine, cosine, tangent, and their inverses. It also  reviews the laws of sine and cosine.

Description: The special triangles 45-45-90, 30-60-90, and equilateral triangle are covered in this study guide.

Description: This study guide reviews the terminology for circles (tangent, arcs, central angles) and the equation for a circle.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide looks at theorems of arcs and angles.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide looks at theorems for inscribed angles and polygons.

Resource Name: Circles: Segments and Lengths Study Guide
Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: Theorems for chords, secants, and tangents (of a circle) are covered in this study guide.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide reviews the formulas for the perimeter and area of triangles and different types of quadrilaterals.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson

Description: This study guide reviews how to classify polyhedra, Euler's formula, and regular polyhedra.

Description: This study guide gives an overview of isometric view, orthographic view, cross section, and nets.

Description: This study guide reviews the surface area and volume of prisms and cylinders.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide reviews the surface area and volume of pyramids and cones.

Description: This study guide looks at the characteristics of spheres, surface area, and volume of spheres.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide is an overview of reflection, rotation, translation, and dilation.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide looks at glides, multiple reflections, and multiple rotations.

Authors: Nicole Crawford; Jane Li; Amy Shen; Zachary Wilson
Description: This study guide is a brief overview of the different types of symmetry and tessellations.

This study guide reviews how experiments and data are collected for statistical analysis. It looks at population vs sample, errors in sampling, bias and methods of reducing bias, and how to use a random number table.

This study guide looks at levels of measurement and the shape, measures of center (median, mean, mode), and measures of spread (standard deviation) of a data set. It also compares the measures for population vs the measures for sample.

Concept EIDs: MAT.STA.223.L.1, MAT.STA.222.L.1, MAT.STA.252.L.1, MAT.STA.226.L.1, MAT.STA.226.2.L.1, MAT.STA.224.L.1
Description: This study guide is an overview of creating bar graphs, pie graphs, frequency tables, histograms, frequency polygons, dot plots, stem-and-leaf plots, and box-and-whisker plots.

Concept EIDs: MAT.STA.422.1.L.1, MAT.STA.422.2.L.1, MAT.PRB.424.L.1, MAT.PRB.425.L.1, MAT.PRB.420.L.1, MAT.PRB.320.L.1, MAT.PRB.322.L.1, MAT.PRB.326.L.1, MAT.PRB.330.L.1, MAT.PRB.332.L.1, MAT.PRB.510.L.1
Description: This study guide reviews the probability of simple events, non-simple events, complementary events, compound events, conditional events, independent events, and mutually exclusive events. It also looks at tree diagrams and counting, combination, and permutation.

This study guide looks at discrete probability distribution and random variables (and notation), the linear transformation of random variable, and characteristics (mean, standard deviation, expected value, standard deviation) of probability distributions.
Binomial experiment, binomial probability, binomial coefficient, and characteristics of the binomial probability distribution are covered in this study guide.
This study guide looks at characteristics of a normal distribution curve, the empirical rule, z-score, standardizing normal curve, and approximating binomial distribution.

This study guide is an overview of displaying two variables in scatter plots and identifying correlation and the correlation coefficient. It also looks at the least-squares regression line and residuals.
Overview of the geometric probability distribution (experiment, probability, and distribution) and Poisson probability distribution (experiment, probability, and distribution).
Introduces sampling distribution and parameter estimation, sampling error, the central limit theorem, confidence intervals, and estimating true mean and true proportion.
Brief overview of the t-distribution and t-test statistic.
Looks at hypothesis testing: null and alternate hypotheses, types of error, p value, how to test a mean hypothesis, and how to test a proportion hypothesis.
Looks at the chi-square statistic, contingency tables, goodness-of-fit test, test for independence, and test for homogeneity.
Review of math in chemistry: precision vs accuracy, calculating error, using units (SI, derived, prefixes), scientific notation, significant figures, and dimensional analysis.
A look at classifying matter (pure, heterogenous vs homogenous mixture, element, compound), the states of matter, chemical vs physical property, and intensive vs extensive property.
Examines subatomic particles, atomic mass unit, charge, mass number, atomic number, isotopes, and average atomic mass mass.

The history of atomic theory: a look at how the model of the atom changes, including Dalton's atomic theory, Thomson's plum pudding model, Rutherford's nuclear model, Bohr's model, and the quantum mechanical model.
A brief look at Schrodinger's equation (brief), orbitals, and the four quantum numbers.
Looks at the behavior of light as a wave and as a particle, Planck's equation, the photoelectric effect, and the atomic emission spectrum.
Goes over the ground state electron configuration (Aufbau principle, Pauli exclusion principle, Hund's rule) and orbital filling diagram.
Looks at how to read a periodic table and identifies classes of elements. Also reviews how to calculate the average atomic mass and the molar mass.
Overview of the relationship between the quantum numbers and the element's position on the periodic table.
Review of various atomic trends: periodicity in ionization energy, electronegativity, affinity, size, and ionic size.

Reviews valence electrons and octet rule and looks at ionic substances (cations, anions, ionic bond, properties), metallic substances (metallic bonds, properties, alloys), and covalent substances (bond, molecule, dipole, properties).
Goes over the rules for naming ions (cations and anions), polyatomic ions, ionic compounds, and covalent compounds.
Looks at how to draw Lewis structures and assign formal charges.

Review of VSEPR theory, molecular geometry, steric number, hybridization (sigma and pi bonds), polar molecules, and polarity. Also goes over how to draw VSEPR structures and determining hybridization and polarity.
Overview of different intermolecular forces and their roles in three phases of matter: gases, liquids, and solids.
A look at phase changes and phase diagrams (in general and for water).

Overview of gases: kinetic theory, ideal gas, barometer and monometer, and gas laws (Boyle's, Charles's, Gay-Lussac's, combined gas, Avogadro's, ideal gas, Dalton's law of partial pressures, diffusion).
Overview of how to read/write chemical reaction, balancing chemical reactions, types of chemical reactions, and net ionic equations.
Reviews important stoichiometric concepts: mole, molar mass, limiting reagent, yield, percent composition, determining empirical formula, and determining molecular formula.
Looks at enthalpy, heat of reaction, phase changes, Hess's law, entropy, spontaneity, and free energy.

Reviews reaction rate by looking at collision theory, how to calculate reaction rate from graph, how to alter the reaction rate, determining rate law, and interpreting potential energy diagrams (activation energy, activated complex).
Examines equilibrium, equilibrium constant, and Le Chatelier's principle.
Reviews properties of solutions: solute, solvent, concentration, solubility, solubility rules and solubility curves, supersaturated solutions, solubility constants, and colligative properties.
Looks at the properties and definitions (Arrhenius, Brosted-Lowry, Lewis) of acids and bases: nomenclature, pH scale, strong acids/bases, dissociation constant, titration, and buffers.
Looks at redox reactions, oxidation states, half-reactions, electrochemical cells, and electrical potential.
Brief overview of naming organic compounds: rules for naming alkanes, alkyl groups, alkenes, alkynes, cyclic hydrocarbons, and functional groups.
Looks at the four main types of biomolecules: carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids.

Goes over nuclear symbol, nuclear stability, strong nuclear force, nuclear band of stability, radioactive decay (alpha, beta, gamma radiation), fission and fusion, and half-life and radioactive decay.
